poem:
Title: "Tale of Average Woes"

In Yarmouth's heart, amongst the flow,
A T-shirt shouts, "Life is Crap, you know!"
Ex got the house, you're down and out,
A middle-aged lament, no doubt.
But hope, my friends, is part of the mix,
And Starmer, they say, has a bag of tricks.
Even when life feels quite askew,
There's always a sunrise in lieu.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Hope is not enough: people want to know that Keir Starmer can fix things | Gaby Hinsliff “Look at that,” said a middle-aged woman delightedly, stopping halfway down the street in Great Yarmouth to nudge her friend. “Life is crap!” She was pointing to a stall selling slogan T-shirts for a fiver, all bearing those three words in several bleak variations: life is crap because your ex got the house, life is crap because you’re". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
